text: a Logano village is in a very remote
area of Borno State not far away from
chubak the village where all those
schoolgirls were were abducted from and
we understand from survivors that the
funerals are already taking place this
morning at least 17 people were killed
but one survivor said that pretty much
every building in the entire village has
been burnt he said that they arrived
about eleven o'clock at night were there
until three in the morning and then left
in vehicles that they had stolen now
these kinds of attacks in the rural
northeast are going on incessantly
across the Northeast there are sways of
the country where it seems the
insurgents have the upper hand and
they're pretty free to do as much as
they want whereas the military in those
rural areas that pretty much no go areas
to the military so people are extremely
vulnerable there have been a lot of
concerns in those villages near chubak
but even though some extra troops have
been sent up there they're still not
able to stop these kinds of attacks
which are extremely ruthless when these
well armed Islamist militants turn up
right so when the President or
representatives from the government say
we are actually managing to push Booker
her arm back what sort of responses that
get these days well nobody believes a
word of it these days I mean a few
months ago you could have argued that
the campaign against Boko Haram had
managed to contain them to a relatively
small area of the Northeast but since
then we've had the two bomb attacks in
Abuja we've had another bomb attack in
cana at the weekend and now the the
bombings in Jos which are some of the
deadliest for several years and the
ongoing attacks in the Northeast all of
this really leaves Nigerians wondering
where it's all headed and whether
there's any sign that the tide can be
turned against this violence what can
the authorities do because apart from
speaking a little bit faster following
the attacks and condemning them quicker
Nigerians have pretty little faith that
much else is being done and it leaves
people really worried about where this
country is headed and we'll obviously if
there are more attacks and bigger
attacks that
takes more firepower more material
assistance where is it all coming from
well that's the question people think
that maybe some of the weapons have come
down from from Libya some of the weapons
being used by Islamist militants but
they've also received ransom payments
before there are a lot of weapons easily
available in the region but
interestingly on the bomb attacks i went
to Jos for one of the church bombings
about two years ago and that church was
flimsily built and it it collapsed and I
think less than 10 people were killed
but these attacks and the ones in in Jos
they're clearly using far more
sophisticated bomb-making equipment the
craters are deep and just from the scene
of devastation that Joss and also in
Abuja it's clear that the insurgents
have really changed their tactics
they're using far more sophisticated
bomb-making equipment and that again is
another huge concern for people and for
the authorities trying to stop these
attacks
